text: a monster is how the president described
cyclone Pam and it destroyed most of
what was in its way
Vanuatu is used to storms but these
homes weren't built to withstand winds
of 200 miles an hour all the houses were
blown out everybody has lost all their
properties and the Red Cross says that a
hundred and thirty thousand people have
been affected that's about half the
population many many Islanders like this
man and his children now have nowhere to
live power is still down across the
archipelago and a lack of running water
has raised fears of disease a race is
now on to get aid to those who need it
military planes from Australia and New
Zealand have brought the first
much-needed supplies the big concern now
is for people in remote islands from
where nothing has been heard absolutely
critical we can make contact as soon as
possible so we can really get an idea of
the of the sense of the devastation that
these an outer Island communities with a
face can we can only assume complete
devastation touted as a tourist paradise
Vanuatu is now in the grip of a major
disaster so far the main losses we know
of have been a property and livelihoods
rather than lives but aid workers still
fear that whole communities could have
been wiped out by the storm Caroline
Hawley BBC news
